title: What Does Choose the Bear Mean on TikTok & X?

steps.title: Most women chose the bear when asked the viral man vs. bear question.
steps.content: Most women chose the bear when asked the viral man vs. bear question. The man vs. bear question is, â€œWould you rather be alone in the woods with a bear or a man?â€ The question is primarily targeted at women and asks if they would feel safer if they were alone with a bear or a random man. Itâ€™s not about the threat of bears in the forest. Itâ€™s about the dangers women face living among men. [1] X Research source The question is meant to highlight womenâ€™s perception of danger by giving them a fictional choice to see what their first response would be. For the most part, the question was asked and answered in a somewhat tongue-in-cheek manner with the reasons women would choose a bear over a man being more serious. The man vs. bear question was intended as a hypothetical situation to help explain how women feel in the presence of men.

steps.title: Women theorized the worst a bear would do is kill them.
steps.content: Women theorized the worst a bear would do is kill them. Most women who responded to the questions gave their reasons. These reasons focused on how the bear would act vs. how the man would act and how society reacts to bear attacks vs. gender-based violence. steps.title: Some women said bears are more predictable than men.
steps.content: Some women said bears are more predictable than men. This was a common refrain from women who live near bears or enjoy solo outdoor activities like hunting, biking, or hiking. They said that there are strategies for dealing with bears because bears are usually predictable, whereas men are not. steps.title: The question evolved into a discussion about violence against women.
steps.content: The question evolved into a discussion about violence against women. Women talked about how they are taught to go places in groups and put keys between their fingers to make a weapon to stay safe at night. steps.title: Many people shared statistics about violence against women.
steps.content: Many people shared statistics about violence against women. Many women and a few men felt this was a good opportunity to raise awareness of violence against women. The statistics illustrated why women thought of strange men as more dangerous than bears. steps.title: â€œChoose the Bearâ€ started as a TikTok post by @callmebkbk.
steps.content: â€œChoose the Bearâ€ started as a TikTok post by @callmebkbk. On March 19, 2024, @callmebkbk posted a video where he explained why it was understandable that a woman would choose a bear over a random man if she were alone in the woods. In one month, the post got 2.3 million views and 340,700 likes. [11] X Research source @callmebkbk was responding to a comment on an unknown post. Later that day, another TikTok user @thottimami69420 shared a post stating that she would choose the bear and gave her reasons why. Her post got 4.2 million views and 1.1 million likes in a month.

steps.title: A @screenshothq post showed 7 out of 8 women choosing the bear.
steps.content: A @screenshothq post showed 7 out of 8 women choosing the bear. This video post is of a street interview where 8 women are asked, â€œWould you rather be stuck in a forest with a man or a bear?â€ Seven out of the eight women in the video answered they would choose the bear with little or no hesitation. [12] X Research source This post went viral, getting over 14 million views and 2 million likes in 3 weeks.

steps.title: Comedian Leslie Jones posted the TikTok video to X.
steps.content: Comedian Leslie Jones posted the TikTok video to X. Jones made her post in April 2024, stating that she would also choose the bear. The man vs. bear question went on to go viral on X, with more and more people sharing their opinions on that platform.

steps.title: Media began to report on the trend in late April 2024.
steps.content: Media began to report on the trend in late April 2024. Stories on the man vs. bear question appeared on the parenting and motherhood blog Scary Mommy and on the Today showâ€™s website .
